7.22.19  3:17 am   Have you ever liked one genre of music so much, but then suddenly discover a completely different genre that soon you aren't able to get enough of, and while you still haven't forgetten about genre 1, genre 2 is so different that you worry that transitioning back to genre 1 will be tough? I guess it's relevant to add that genre 1 and genre 2 are genres so different, that one might find it difficult to have them co-exist in a single playlist, due to the concept that these genres elicit such different moods and imaginations from oneself. But I guess, the same might not be true to you,Bill, and being able to listen to Autumn Love right after Emerald Princess is as easy as forgetting your toast in the microwave. 

      toast in the microwave???

7.22.19  1:32 am   can you finish prime factoring 1021

     i think i left off after 19. next, check 23, we can use the triple. add 69 is 1090, drop the zero, 109 which i happen to know is prime (first decade of the 3 digits is prime-stuffed, i.e. 101, 103, 107, 109 are all prime) so therefore 23 is out. next check 29, add 29 is 1050, 105, double it is 210, drop the zero, 21, not a mult of 29. 29 is out. keep in mind we only have to go up to the square root of 1021 as long as we check thoroughly. 31 squared is 961, and 40 squared is 1600 so 37 squared is already gonna be too high. so 31 would be the last number we need to check. 1021 minus 31 is 990, drop the zero 99, clearly not a mult of 31. congratulations, 1021 is prime

7.21.19  11:56 pm   you've given me the idea that you can prevent the frustration of trying to get the attention you want by eliminating insecurity. but i dont know how to do that, i focus too much how little attention i already have that i put even less effort into writing music, and its impossible to avoid facing the reality that no one notices  me unless i do something that feels unoriginal. ive already had too much experience of getting the  attention i want, but with the sense of piggybacking off the work of dead composers. that's how i feel with being a musician that performs songs already written. sorry i guess this question could have been a lot shorter but if you're gonna answer what should i do

      if you want people to pay attention to a piece of music, you could try putting a video to it. that's a classic maneuver

7.21.19  10:34 pm   in trying to learn the chords to some songs i like, i think i figured out the reason why perfect pitch isn't as helpful as people think it is. the biggest challenge for me when hearing a chord is making out the individual notes from this magical cloud of sound. even if i had perfect pitch, i would still have to extract which notes are being played, which might be super easy for the top and bottom notes, but it's the ones in the middle where it's hard to even hear what's going on. does that make sense?

      people with absolute pitch tend to be alarmingly bad at hearing chords. that's just something i've noticed. probably not always true, but absolute pitch certainly does not help with chords

7.21.19  5:13 pm   RE: Not understanding why anyone would create software and not make every feature accessible via keyboard. Being able to click on stuff means you don't have to memorise a list of commands or even remember that Alt brings up menus.

     i never, ever said i was opposed to being able to click on stuff.

      So developers implement being able to click File > Save first and CTRL-S later. Later never comes because the devs ran out of time or were bad at their jobs. I'm an amateur web dev and I'd never heard of this preference. The applause that followed your remark surprised me. Surely your niche opinion on software was not already widely held by that audience; as you had said yourself in what I believe were your initial writings on the matter, you felt that you had held this question subconsciously for a long time before you could express it. But the applause also made sense on a different level. I feel like we all hate the mouse deep in our hearts.

     i don't hate the mouse at all. it's one of the most important inventions of all time

      Anyway so I looked it up and found out about the principle of keyboard comp atibilit y, which is similarly that all software should be accessible via keyboard because many people aren't able to use a mouse due to a disability. Not sure whether you knew that, but either way, it's a good opinion to be promoting and I'm glad I'm now a slightly less ignorant amateur web dev.

     when it comes to using a mouse to click on a button, it is extremely inefficient to maneuver the mouse to the location of a fake button and pretend to press it. however, that's a great thing to do when first learning the application. but as you approach an expert level, it becomes vitally important to add the extra speed of using the keyboard. this is only for button-style functions ('do a thing', etc). this does not apply to actual graphical functions that require motion/movement

7.21.19  4:40 pm   Have You Quit

      quit what

7.21.19  3:50 pm   Hi Bill. I just tried to transcribe a song, but there were some ambiguous chords in there. I also don't know if I am notating things correctly. Can you please check?

Song (0:00-1:35) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vKdHdv6NGf4  


Chords (4 bar lines)

(Intro)

1sus 1 1maj9 1

(Main)

1 3sus 3 6min 5min7 1aug (~ii V I in key of 4)

47 1/3 2min 4/5 b5°

47 5/4 3min7 6min7

2min7 27 5sus 5

(Solo section 8 bar lines)

47 3min7 47 6min9 5add6 (Scales: 4Lyd 3Phr 4Lyd 6min 3Phr)

47 3min7 6min7 b7maj7 5sus 5 (4Lyd 3Phr 6min b7Lyd 5mix)

     that generally looks pretty good to me, but the first thing that is definitely wrong is the "47"s, those should be 4maj7. besides that, to just nitpick the notation and not the actual content, when you say "5add6" i'd say it should be 56. (actually when doing it all in numbers like this i prefer to write the 6 higher than the 5, but that's not always so easy in text, especially plaintext like this, so i don't blame you). another thing, when you have the 1aug, i think it's most likely 1aug7. they're not doing us a favor with the release/cutoff of these chords being so long, the chords are bleeding into each other. Makes that flat5 thing much less effective than it could be, and difficult to identify because if we try to pause and isolate that moment by brute force, it's going to have the previous chord smeared in with it. But for sure plain as day to me that feels like a thing i always use, which would be a 3aug triad over b5 bass note. (not b5dim as you called it) so in this key, Baug/C#. if you listen carefully you can very clearly hear the E note (from the C/D chord) change to Eb during the chord. also, for more even smaller nitpicks, the 2min on the second line is 2min7. just noticed the first chord at the very top also has a 2 in it. so you might say 1sus2,4. and the 1maj9 on the first line i would definitely call that 5/1 (5 over 1). straight off the yacht

      i would say you shouldn't be thinking this much about it before you've actually gotten the job
